comments.commentBody:
If California voters vote to legalize cannabis, then it is game over for it being illegal. California has 1/6 of the US population. It is one things fro low population states to legalize it, but with California added to the mix, nearly 1/3 of the population will have some form of legal access in the western US.

Thus, the US government should just do what is right and remove it from Schedule 1 substances. It is time that the failed war on drugs come to an end.
You may recall that President Clinton never endorsed the Kyoto protocols or asked the Senate to ratify them.  Bush never took us out, because Clinton never put us in.  You have a convenient memory.
"Imagine a President...saying, sorry, the United States no longer believes in science" - that would be revisiting President George W. Bush taking us out of the Kyoto protocols.
Yes, I don't see any rush to take public transportation or even push for more of it or skip flying in planes ... but we all want someone to "do" something.

Individual actions will not solve the problem.  We either have group actions to address it or we live with the unsolved problem.  But for free market conservatives, group action organized and compelled by government, is worse than extinction, a fate worse than death.

So you claim that global warming is lethal, yet you won't lift a finger to curb your dreaded carbon footprint? Are you proud to be a murderer?  The immorality and idiocy of the left are on full display!

Many people who accept the science of climate change do what they can. But they can only do what's within the limits of what's available or possible . Where I live there is no recycling pickup so every 2 weeks we bring our recycling to a center. However they can't process glass right now. Although I know it's bad for landfills, but I have to throw it away. I drive a fuel efficient car but would rather drive an all electric powered by solar panels. But I live in a condo so solar panels are not an option - I rely on the electric utilities.

Good public policy can make an impact on a personal level (to your point) and more importantly, alter the bigger picture. How much choice do you have as an individual, as to whether your electricity comes from coal, nuclear or natural gas? Unless you generate your own, the answer is not much. But public policy can and does influence such things. If you vote against good-for-climate public policy then what you do as an individual doesn't count for much.

Good column, Tim.  Now a question for you and others here: did you scrap your car(s) yet so the metal could be used for solar panels or windmills? Are you reading by candlelight at night or - gasp - do you use coal powered or natural gas powered electricity? (And I'm still trying to find out if Al Gore has scrapped his jet.  If anyone knows, please reply.)
We are not going to win. Explain to those who come up in the drive by windows who want a coffee (double/double) and a doughnut for breakfast and tell them they are hurting the atmosphere?

Hypocrites, al if them. I don't know one liberal person who is willing to give up their job or creature comforts. The extremely liberal guy down the street from me has two SUV's. TWO!  He "needs" them.

American capitalism is what it is.  Why is anyone surprised.  However, I'd much rather go to a SEC school and have fun, fun, fun than some lame academic only school with career obsessed people and not so hot ladies.  But, that's just me.Vist the University of Chicago and you would see what I mean.  The women are beat down looking, but really, really smart, if thats what you like.

One problem:  That Exxon board was in their 60s in the mid-70s, which was 40 years ago.  Most of them have been dead and buried for decades; those still alive are in nursing homes, trying to remember their own names.  Kind of hard to prosecute the dead and demented.
Nice story, except for the fact that decades ago we were being warned of global cooling and the coming Ice Age.  The science was settled!

"They found that Exxon’s board of directors was fully briefed by its own scientists, decades ago, on the emerging consensus that burning oil and gas may cause sea levels to rise, glacial ice to melt and a host of other “generally negative consequences.” Their reaction was to fund the kind of counter-information campaigns that Soviet-era propagandists would be proud of."

When you put out finanical projections that people rely upon to decide whether to buy or sell your stock, "cooking the books" is a no-no. So are materially misleading statements made knowingly.

Somevobdy should end up going to jail. ExxonMobil should pay some very large fines. Shades of Enron.

I find it fascinating and terribly discouraging that in 2015 we're still discussing a sport in which women have esentially one role: that of cheerleaders. That women are not sharing in the rewards of Alabama's football cash cow is just an example of how entrenched in sexism this entire state continues to be.
Imagine if in 2015 the University of Alabama had a college athletic program in which any other group was delegated to observer/cheerleader status. Suppose that African Americans, Asians or Jews were not allowed to participate in the sport,were not given a comparable team on which they could play or were denied lucrative athletic scholarships and the obscenely high salaries that coaches receive. There would be a public outcry that would shock the university into action. But the fact that women are exempt from these opportunities by virtue of their gender is never even discussed,much less addressed.
How much longer is the public going accept this illegal,pervasive,blatant and damaging institutional sexism on behalf of universities like Alabama? Given that this is an institution whose mission it is to educate,their policies of gender discrimination and exclusion are certainly lessons well learned by the majority of students. Just look at how this state operates by having power weilded by a handful of corporate males and a legislature that is predominantly comprised of men and you will see that this the kids are getting the message: men are highly valued; women aren't.
Yes! And it's happened - remember the excitement around going to the moon?

I know this isn't a sports page article, but it should be pointed out that the University's student population and academic reputation have been growing for far longer than the football team has been bringing in championships (in the post-Bryant era).

As late as 2003 under Mike Shula, the Tide posted a 4-9 record. In 2000, under Mike Dubose, the Tide won all of three games. In Nick Saban's first year, 2007, it won seven and lost six. It is a great football program now, and it was a great football program during Bear's era, but with the exception of Gene Stalling's tenure (1990-1996), it was a very mediocre program, until Saban arrived.

Of course winning championships brings in money and expands the pool of potential students. But winning championships to the point that they are now almost expected is a relatively recent phenomenon.

I graduated from Alabama in 1985 and barely recognize the place when I go back. It has over twice as many students as when I was there and new buildings at every turn. All that development couldn't have taken place in the six years since Alabama football got back to its championship winning ways.

But this was a good article, one of few I've ever read from the NYTimes about some aspect of the state of Alabama that wasn't obviously slanted and derogatory, as if the writer was looking down his nose at Alabama while he wrote. It mainly stuck to the facts. The comments on the other hand...whew!

But, Roll Tide!

Why would they be sent to jail? You can't jail a corporation, you only fine or tax them. I am sure you have done things in your life that were not "earth friendly". Would you like to be investigated and put in jail because you forgot to recycle that milk carton and helped destroy the planet? I didn't think so.
Be careful for what you wish for, it might come true.

And just who will this prosecution hurt? The tens of thousands of retired investors who rely, directly or indirectly, on ExxonMobil dividends for retirement income.

And who will this prosecution help? The New York Attorney General and his political ambitions.

Pathetic.
The only person who needs to go to jail is the Attorney General for advancing a frivolous lawsuit.

As usual, no human being will be sent to jail. Just one more corporate financial penalty. Until real people are sent to jail, corporate criminal behavior will continue  - just part of doing business, folks. Why shouldn't it? Because it wrecks lives? Not a chance.

You have no clue if you think admission exceptions do not exist at private schools Stanford, Duke , Northwestern, Vanderbilt, Wake Forest, Tulane, etc.... or in the "public Ivies" (Texas, Michigan, Virginia, UNC, Ga Tech, UCLA, Cal etc...). Most of the players on the rosters of those teams are not competitive with the admission standards normally applied.

No people around 50 million years ago, so it is not analogous.

No agriculture either. So no food for billions of people.

colleges should shut down their academic programs and just have football teams

lets dispense w th pretense that any learning other than th i formation is going on there
In a way, you are right to say what you did: he article did sound a bit waaaay to rosy.  Most NYT writers are a bit more if not cynical then not outright cheerleaders of the subjects they cover.

"You are using a serious global problem to score points against the Republicans."....Which is not only justified, but indeed an obligation - if you are not part of the solution you are part of the problem.

Although social "policy change" would help many families tremendously in cutting the cost and stress of finding good child care, it seems that some of the essence of this irreconcilable conflict is personal. My own husband said to me, " know one is going to go to the grave wishing they would have worked more". I agree.  Money does help put food on the table, but if either or both parents work, work should not come between enjoying the blessings of having children and a loving spouse. After completing a medical residency program that necessitated 80 hours a week of work, I said enough, I choose not to work full time. It is not worth losing those precious moments. I have colleagues who are not married to physicians and have left their careers to care for their children or spouses, men and female alike. different ethnicities as well (the world is bigger than black,white, latina and asian by the way). Work can help life but work does not nor should, equal life.

I liked riding those cable cars in San Francisco, Bobbie. It's another special place, for sure!

The two things I think would surprise people about the Philadelphia trolley system - 1) riding a regular trolley car through deep woods on the Media line in spring or fall, seeing all that beauty from that clickety-clack vantage point,
and 2) riding a regular trolley car through the subway tunnels, on the way into the city to visit grandmom at Wanamaker's store.
Most people only know trolleys, if at all, as urban, street-level phenomena.

Even if Exxon lied, whatever that even means, its lies had zero effect on the climate and on anyone's perceptions, delusions or knowledge about the climate. Unlike tobacco companies, which produced tobacco and were in a position to know the details of research about it, Exxon is not in the business of producing the climate and cannot be assumed to know much if anything at all about it. It may know something about CO2, which is a byproduct of its products' use. But again, unlike tobacco, it is a byproduct of nearly EVERYTHING any of us does, including breathing out. Exxon has nothing even close to unique control over how much CO2 gets into the atmosphere whereas tobacco companies had huge control of tobacco in that way. Moreoever, the science of tobacco's impact was settled, unlike CO2's role in climate change, and (more importantly) it had KILLED people. Many here may entertain fantasies about CO2 doing that, but I defy anyone to offer evidence of it killing a single soul, let alone evidence that any of Exxon's CO2 molecules did so.

This is a totally absurd grandstanding ploy, and I for one hope Exxon bates it away like the fly on the shoulder it is.

Please recommend the first 10 biggest elected liars. Remember, it is all connected to military industrial complex, war is good business, Saddam is acquiring WMDz, and Netanyahu has never deceived people.

The Attorney General's efforts would be better spent investigating lies, broken promises and cover ups by the elected officials. No need for subpoenas, the information needed is in the public domain.  Term limits, the only answer.

You should Wiki Tragedy of the Commons sometime. More enlightening yet, pick up Ishmael by Daniel Quinn.

I do empathize with you and all those employed in things that stink up our atmosphere. As hard as it is to reconcile, the costs to leave over 50% of all those fossil fuel "assets" in the ground pales, according to most of the biggest insurance companies, according to the Secretary of the Navy, according to the CIA, USDA, EPA, pales in comparison to the losses of lives, ruination of coastline buildings and infrastructure, lose of food production capacity, and vast migrations of peoples to places in the Northern Hemisphere escaping desertification and mass extinctions and ecosystem function failures nearer the equator. Ever think like a frog put in a pot set to boil before?

I'm a little confused about what the government is trying to accomplish here. Oil producers not only produce oil but also produe wealth around the world. Many  petroleum producing nations need to sell oil to survive. It's wishfull thinking to say the world cou)d stop using oil in decades. Countries like China experiencing explosive growth need to clean up their air. Like the us
This is the same NOVA that got their butts handed to them in a hearing with Ted Cruz regarding "the Pause".  You tube it.
There, there Phillip. You believed Reagan and Dubbya because you are a Republican. All of us lefties are here to deprive you of your weapons and ship them to Muslims in Iran.
Thanks for speaking the truth, Kevin!

Lets also investigate the so called environmentalists for their lies.  In the 80's they told us we had 20 years to save the oceans, Gore telling us we would be under water by now.  Remember they told us the caribou would die if the Alaska pipeline were built. The polar bears are alive and thriving. All this is based on computer models.

Go ahead, do Red-baiting if you have nothing productive to say.
Are you going to try for a new blacklist next?
"Are you now or have you ever been an environmentalist?"
"Are you now or have you ever been somebody who cared about the future of our children, the future of life on this planet?"

I think we should begin writing to our Congress people that bills should be introduced to eliminate all sources of evil carbon dioxide (you know, that stuff that produces our oxygen!). Let's get rid of cows (oops, they're trying to regulate their excrement already), birds, lions, tigers and bears, and humans!! Get rid of everything that breathes. All produce too much climate change. Or is it climate warming, I forget.

Greens are the old Reds. Very dangerous. Resist

Ha, ha.  Antarctic ice?  The vast majority of estimates for sea level rise don't include any melting in the Antarctic, northern hemisphere ice is the immediate problem.  Much of Antarctica averages 30'degrees BELOW ZERO.  It has been hoped that it will take centuries for warming to be sufficient to melt Antarctic ice, so "yes" some glaciers would naturally be growing and spreading, same as usual.  Unfortunately, there are signs of melting on the edges of the norther most regions.  Antarctic ice is beginning to melt way ahead of estimates.  Still a long way off.
